ImageData.LabelName: Stage III Nonmelanoma Skin Cancer of the Head and Neck (1)

OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Under the panel “c”, removed the words “Tissue below the subcutaneous tissue”; added "the Head and Neck" to the title
No changes made since previous version (rev5)
Changed text in inset box to "Tumor is larger than 4 cm"; and changed text under the middle panel to "Tissue below subcutaneous tissue"
Made all the fonts the same size

Added Skin Cancer to title; added a third block that shows cancer extending from the surface, through the tissue beneath the subcutaneous layer, to a piece of bone underneath; labeled bone; labeled the pull-out "a", the first block "b", the middle block "c", and the new block "d"; deleted the current part b

Split the tissue block in half, with the cancer going down to the nerve in one half (labelled c) and to the area beneath the subcutaneous layer in the other half (labelled d); for label b, removed the inset with the woman’s head and added arrow coming off of the main block to a picture of a bone with the label “Cancer spreads to nearby bone”; and removed parentheses from the labels a, b, c, and d.
Image revisions made per AJCC 8th edition updates
Part one of two-part revised illustration.

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Stage III nonmelanoma skin cancer of the head and neck (1); drawing shows (a) an inset showing that the tumor is larger than 4 centimeters and that 4 centimeters is about the size of a walnut. Also shown is cancer spreading through the epidermis to (b) tissue covering the nerves below the dermis; (c) below the subcutaneous tissue; and (d) bone.

Stage III nonmelanoma skin cancer of the head and neck (1); drawing shows (a) an inset showing that the tumor is larger than 4 centimeters and that 4 centimeters is about the size of a walnut. Also shown is cancer spreading through the epidermis to (b) tissue covering the nerves below the dermis; (c) below the subcutaneous tissue; and (d) bone.

Captions.MediaCaption: Stage III nonmelanoma skin cancer of the head and neck (1). The tumor is (a) larger than 4 centimeters; or cancer has spread to (b) tissue covering the nerves below the dermis; or (c) below the subcutaneous tissue; or (d) the bone and the bone has minor damage. Cancer may have spread to one lymph node on the same side of the body as the tumor and the node is 3 centimeters or smaller, and cancer has not spread through to the outside covering of the lymph node.

Stage III nonmelanoma skin cancer of the head and neck (1). The tumor is (a) larger than 4 centimeters; or cancer has spread to (b) tissue covering the nerves below the dermis; or (c) below the subcutaneous tissue; or (d) the bone and the bone has minor damage. Cancer may have spread to one lymph node on the same side of the body as the tumor and the node is 3 centimeters or smaller, and cancer has not spread through to the outside covering of the lymph node.

ProposedUse.Glossary: stage III nonmelanoma skin cancer on the head and neck (not on the eyelid)
